public interface Transceiver extends NamedObject, Receiver, Transmitter
Functionality that is common to Broadcasters, Listeners, Repeaters and potentially other classes that are involved in handling messages. The Transmitter.isTransmitting() method returns true if transmitting is enabled. The Receiver.isReceiving() method returns true if receiving is enabled. When enabled, the Receiver.receive(Transmittable) method calls onReceive(Transmittable) (Transmittable)} to allow the subclass to handle the message.

Convenience Methods

The following convenience methods call Receiver.receive(Transmittable) with the appropriate class of message.

  • announce*() - The sends a formatted Announcement message to this Transceiver
  • trace*() - The sends a formatted Trace message to this Transceiver
  • information*() - The sends a formatted Information message to this Transceiver
  • narrate() - The sends a formatted Narration message to this Transceiver
  • warning*() - The sends a formatted Warning message to this Transceiver
  • glitch*() - The sends a formatted Glitch message to this Transceiver/li>
  • quibble*() - The sends a formatted Quibble message to this Transceiver/li>
  • problem*() - The listener handles a Problem message
  • fatal*() - The sends a formatted FatalProblem message to this Transceiver
  • halted*() - The sends a formatted OperationHalted message to this Transceiver

Debugging

A Transceiver provides access to a Debug object which has the class context (also CodeContext) provided by the method debugClassContext().

The isDebugOn() provides convenient access to Debug.isDebugOn() and the ifDebug(Runnable) executes the given code if debugging is on. Several convenience methods also provide tracing which originates Trace messages only if debugging is on.

Because Broadcasters, Listeners and Repeaters are debug transceivers, they inherit all the methods in this class. This means that a subclass of BaseRepeater can simply call a trace() or glitch() method and it will automatically be gated by the functionality of Debug. This makes it especially easy to declare and control debug tracing. In the example below, the trace() statement can be enabled by running the application with -DKIVAKIT_DEBUG=EmployeeLoader. See @Debug for more details on the KIVAKIT_DEBUG syntax.

Debug Tracing Example 

 class EmployeeLoader extends BaseRepeater
 {

     [...]

     trace("Loaded $ employees", employees.size());

 }
* @author jonathanl (shibo)
See Also:
Listener, Broadcaster, Message, Trace, Information, Warning, Glitch, Problem, OperationHalted
